static server for all FE services in pipedrive
js, html, css, etc. other static assets - served from CDN - all from JURA

files hashed because need unique name
through JURA files get uploaded to S3
when deploying services, knows where each service is on the network
possible - if jura doesnt have on disk nor S3, will redirect request
e.g. cashed on CDN but u want to fetch from ur own service

componentLoader handles caching of a component
writes definitions of file aliases (to hashed versions) to consul
componentLoader gets urls with cdn links to hashed files and then can load
can access previous versions of files
thus no need to re-build & re-deploy the project!
rollback is interesting n cool - we don't really do anything - we only update which "bucket" of files we want to use, their hashes get loaded and FE app automatically updates
tho not really needed for us
though there's still kubernetes n stuff
arg2 = specific component defined in webpack config
if empty, defaults to the empty field from the webpack config of the project it is from (e.g. if from projet `froot` then resolves to froot's webpack config's empty field)
we don't want people to use it just yet

each tribe does testing differently. tho mostly jest (we migrated from mocha and regret it LMAO) + react-testing-lib
working currently on v5 - main focus on theming (not dark mode, but individual stuff like e.g. tailwind)
every 6h we download the files, update cached version in the cdn,
configured in package.json - needs 2 scripts - check & upload, & a translator field with some config

on a new mission, mission leads & PMs define what metrics we need to track & then we implement

like most tools, it's specific to (segmented by) the datacenter's region (e.g. it's needed to specify the segment in url)
graylog - stores all the logs (both frontend and backend)
what our support uses to help our customers

#aha this makes me further realize that the tools organizations create are very much a reflection of how they operate themselves. I think there was a law described about this ?? upd: I just re-discovered [[conway's law]] lol

re: "useless" - nothing is inherently useless, because in the process of learning X, you learn & experience things more or less related, but still outside of X as well, and if X becomes useless, the other stuff prevails

re: #google - completely opposite - internal tools are very much internal, and if you learn them well, but then leave google - a lot of your knowledge becomes __useless__ ((gu9uGUwpV)). the ultimate golden handcuffs. hell no.

the implications of this are big. one motivates the user to become smarter, to understand how the system works underneath, __and__ allows them to do it, all while not creating wrappers on top of existing programs, meaning that the knowledge you again is just as valuable outside the current setup
because in some cases nothing should be abstracted - then the choice is having a template instead of a library, or copy-pasted / #wet (as opposed to #DRY) code
yet again #react's philosophy checks out - abstract the most important bits, and let the community grow & develop everything else. eventually, if things mature enough, we come back to:
and sometimes very little things need to be abstracted - then we can create & extract more sophisticated & extendable programs but keep everything else as a template.

what can be learnt from this is that maybe one should never create an #abstraction (both 1) a utility function on some "reusable logic" and 2) a library/framework instead of a template) on top of some logic __without__ first using it enough to realize the common use cases to identify the things that can and __should__ be abstracted, and only then start abstracting.
the convenience of consumption, at the loss of  simplicity of modification

but then, the program becomes much more complex, with all the stuff that comes from that! and remember, what we tried turning into packages were actually small utilities/scripts - they didn't have any of the problems - the problems come from wanting to abstract those small utilities into packages
unless, ofc, the program would be completely extensible, meaning it would provide APIs to extend the behavior without modifying the program itself (O in [[SOLID principles]] - open-closed)

but then it'd be harder for the end user of it to modify it (e.g. the util currently lives in `~/.local/bin/`, and if it was a package / program that you'd install, it'd live in e.g. `/usr/local/bin/`, meaning that if u were to modify it, your changes would get overriden - you'd have to contribute directly to the original package by e.g. opening PRs on github, but you don't control if they get merged or not, so now you'd have to fork the repository which contains this program, and then modify it and potentially maintain the fork, plus you'd have the burdain of publishing the package yourself w/ a different name)
1. __at first__ - don't abstract anything - use the existing primitive tools (e.g. the programming language itself)
2. then, find: what you end up repeating a lot, or what mistakes you failing at, or similar
3.1 don't try solving multiple problems at once -- [[UNIX philosphy]] - one small independent thing at once

on one end, you can create hacks on top of your existing solutions (i.e. close(r) to your leaf nodes of the abstraction hierarchy), but that usually doesn't go a long way, and/or cripples everything else.
on the complete opposite end, you maybe could create APIs in the very beginning of your abstraction hierarchy (e.g. on the OS level), but that might be extremely hard to 1) do, and 2) do __right__.
maybe see also: tree balancing (computer science), tho dunno if any useful (yet).
the hierarchy of your abstractions also matters, and it's hard to balance (this might be the essence of what this is all about, but I'm not sure yet):
3.2 if you __do__ feel like solving multiple problems -- you might be operating at the wrong level of [[the abstraction hierarchy]]:
3.3 make sure 5. still applies to other existing abstractions.
3. then, think about the absolute minimal solution that would solve your problem (singular)
4. if everything makes sense, you are confident your solution sits at the right level of abstraction hierarchy - implement it
5. as time goes on - re-evaluate if the solution still makes sense and still sits at the right level of [[abstraction hierarchy]]
so in essence, what it comes down to is:
[[Luke Smith (amazing linux stuff)]] yet again [[was right]] (especially for the specific use case / need that #[[voidrice (public)]]] provides)

old: damn, I love roam not only because it makes writing fun/the norm for me, but that it lets my mind discover connections between things when writing
damn, I love roam not only because it makes writing fun/the norm for me, but that the act of writing itself lets my mind discover connections between things

#aha #public YO, the react vs angular principle, the debate of 
 having a forkable template vs creating a whole library to wrap around the tools you'd have in the same template -- I just realized the same story applies with linux distros!!! #arch + #larbs - minimal, larbs is just minimal utilities/scripts + some default configs of programs e.g. i3, meanwhile e.g. manjaro & others have a lot of stuff abstracted away, some even create wrapper programs that operate on top of existing ones
